moves.1. d4: When you see d4, you should probably expect c4 as the second move.  One of these days, I might learn to recognize all these openings.
moves.2. c4 d6: The early d6 makes this the Old Indian defense, but it all goes to the same place.
moves.3. Nc3 g6 4. e3 Bg7 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Bd3 Nb: What I like about this opening is that it gives you a lot of options.  You can attack with the e pawn, or the c pawn, or you can stay closed and develop the b pawn.  Against a weak opponent, this opening seems to work well.  In this case, this was not a weak opponent.
Sometimes, against a stronger player, it seems logical to take the queen.  But, then again, it simplifies the game for the stronger player, too, and this isn't necessarily good.  I reminded myself to watch the c6 pawn with this note:
13. Bxd1 b6
moves.13. Rxd1 b6 14. Rb1 Bd7 15. Nc3 Rab8: I don't think I had a coherent plan in this game.  This move seems like a waste, but I suppose, now looking back, that I wanted to attack the c4 pawn.
